org.gearman.util
Class ArgumentParser

java.lang.Object
  org.gearman.util.ArgumentParser
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Iterable<ArgumentParser.Option>
public final class ArgumentParser
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Iterable<ArgumentParser.Option>

An argument parser that follows the GNU argument and option convention.

GNU Convention:
01. Arguments are options if they begin with a hyphen delimiter ('-').
02. Multiple options may follow a hyphen delimiter in a single token if the options do not take arguments. Thus, '-abc' is equivalent to '-a -b -c'.
03. Certain options require an argument. For example, the '-o' command of the ld command requires an argumentâ€”an output file name.
04. An option and its argument may or may not appear as separate tokens. (In other words, the whitespace separating them is optional.) Thus, '-o foo' and '-ofoo' are equivalent.
05. The argument "--" terminates all options; any following arguments are treated as non-option arguments, even if they begin with a hyphen.
06. A token consisting of a single hyphen character is interpreted as an ordinary non-option argument.
07. Options may be supplied in any order, or appear multiple times. The interpretation is left up to the particular application program.
08. Long name options consist of '--' followed by a name made of alphanumeric characters and dashes.
09. A Long name option's argument may be two separate tokens, or specified by the '=' symbol. "--threads=4" is equivalent to "--threads 4"
10. Long name options only need to be uniquely identified. For example, "--th=4" is equivalent to "--threads=4" if the prefix "--th" can only belong the the option "--threads"

Note: this class is not thread-safe

Author:
isaiah

Method Detail

addOption

public final boolean addOption(char shortname,
                               java.lang.String longname,
                               boolean takesArgument)
Registers an option with the argument parser

Parameters:
shortname - A single char representing the option's short name. If, for example, -v flags the option, this value should be 'v'
longname - A string representing the option's long name. If, for example, --version flags the option, this value should be "version"
takesArgument - If true, the option being added is expected to accept an argument. Otherwise the option takes no argument
Returns:
Returns true if the option was added successfully. Adding a new option will fail if an option's shortname or longname is already used

removeOption

public final boolean removeOption(char shortname)
Removes the option with the given shortname.

Parameters:
shortname - The sortname that identifies the option to be removed
Returns:
Returns true if the option was removed

removeOption

public final boolean removeOption(java.lang.String longname)
Removes a registered option by its long name

Parameters:
longname - The option's long name
Returns:
true if the option was removed

parse

public final java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> parse(java.lang.String[] args)
Parses the given command line arguments into a set of options and argument. To retrieve the flagged options, use the iterator() method

Parameters:
args - The set of command line arguments
Returns:
The set of arguments that were not parsed into options. null is returned if parsing failed.

iterator

public java.util.Iterator<ArgumentParser.Option> iterator()
Returns an iterator for iterating over the set of flagged options

Specified by:
iterator in interface java.lang.Iterable<ArgumentParser.Option>

close

public final void close()
Closes the argument parser. Free resources and locks the object
